skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for assertionValue is given.
An asserted value, if it is numeric.
The units associated with the value in assertionValueNumeric.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Ontology of Units of Measure http://www.wurvoc.org/vocabularies/om-1.8/ of SI units, derived units, or other non-SI units accepted for use within the SI. For units that are composed of multiple parts, use the patterns as given in "A Primer for Communicating Mathematics via Plain Text" (https://cse.sc.edu/~fenner/latex-ASCII.pdf) by Stephen Fenner (e.g., `g/cm^3` for grams per cubic centimeter). For other units, provide the value as a recognizable standard (e.g., '%') or written out in full and in the plural (e.g., `individuals`). It is fine to provide non-SI units in the original language of the dataset.

skos:definition: The IRI for the units of an assertionValueNumeric.
The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in assertionUnit is given.
A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who made an Assertion.
skos:example: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`, `FMNH`

skos:definition: An identifier for an Agent who made an Assertion.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
skos:example: `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097` (for an individual); `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 | https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0098` (for a list of people)

skos:definition: The names of, references to, or descriptions of the methods or protocols used in making an Assertion.
An identifier for a Protocol used to make an Assertion.
A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with an Assertion.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
skos:example: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

skos:definition: Comments or notes about an Assertion.
An identifier for a Citation.
An identifier for a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: The category that best matches the nature of a Citation.
The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Citation.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in citationType is given.
A bibliographic reference for the resource.
skos:note: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.
skos:example: `Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, UC Berkeley. MVZ Mammal Collection (Arctos). Record ID: http://arctos.database.museum/guid/MVZ:Mamm:165861?seid=101356. Source: http://ipt.vertnet.org:8080/ipt/resource.do?r=mvz_mammal.` (Occurrence example); `https://www.gbif.org/species/2439608 Source: GBIF Taxonomic Backbone` (Taxon example); `Rand, K.M., Logerwell, E.A. The first demersal trawl survey of benthic fish and invertebrates in the Beaufort Sea since the late 1970s. Polar Biol 34, 475–488 (2011). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00300-010-0900-2` (Event example)

skos:definition: The number of the page on which the citation occurs in the cited reference.
skos:note: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.
skos:example: `Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, UC Berkeley. MVZ Mammal Collection (Arctos). Record ID: http://arctos.database.museum/guid/MVZ:Mamm:165861?seid=101356. Source: http://ipt.vertnet.org:8080/ipt/resource.do?r=mvz_mammal.` (Occurrence example); `https://www.gbif.org/species/2439608 Source: GBIF Taxonomic Backbone` (Taxon example); `Rand, K.M., Logerwell, E.A. The first demersal trawl survey of benthic fish and invertebrates in the Beaufort Sea since the late 1970s. Polar Biol 34, 475–488 (2011). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00300-010-0900-2` (Event example)

skos:definition: An identifier for the reference in which a Citation occurs.
The category that best matches the nature of a reference.
The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of reference.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in referenceType is given.
The year the reference in a Citation was published.
An indication of whether the reference for a Citation was peer reviewed.
Comments or notes about a Citation.
An unambiguous reference to a resource within a given context.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to identify a resource by means of a string conforming to a formal identification system.

skos:definition: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: The category or system that best matches the nature of an Identifier.
The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Identifier.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in identifierType is given.
A language in which an Identifier is presented.
skos:note: Recommended best prectice is to use an ISO639-2 three-letter language code.

skos:definition: An identifier for a Media instance.
An identifier for a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: A term to describe the content of the image by a value from a controlled vocabulary.
skos:note: Controlled vocabulary of subjects to support broad classification of media items. Terms from various controlled vocabularies may be used. AC-recommended vocabularies are preferred and MAY be unqualified literals (not a full URI). For terms from other vocabularies either a precise URI SHOULD be used, or, as long as all unqualified terms in all vocabularies are unique, metadata SHOULD provide the source vocabularies using the Subject Category Vocabulary term. The value SHOULD be a string, whose text can also be in the form of a URL. These guidelines on value format are less restrictive than is specified by the IPTC guidelines.

skos:definition: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the subject category of the Media instance.
Any vocabulary or formal classification from which terms in the Subject Category have been drawn.
skos:note: The AC recommended vocabularies do not need to be cited here. There is no required linkage between individual Subject Category terms and the vocabulary; the mechanism is intended to support discovery of the normative URI for a term, but not guarantee it.

skos:definition: An identifier for a Protocol.
An identifier for a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: An identifier for a broader dwc:Event that groups this and potentially other dwc:Events.
The name of a dwc:Event preferred in searches and results.
The category that best matches the nature of a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in dwc:eventType is given.
A name for a dataset from which data originated.
An identifier for a dataset from which data originated.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: An identifier given to a dwc:Event in the field.
skos:note: Often serves as a link between field notes and a dwc:Event.

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations responsible for conducting or recording a dwc:Event.
skos:example: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`, `FMNH`

skos:definition: An identifier for the Agent responsible for conducting or recording a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: The date or time interval during which a dwc:Event occurred.
skos:note: For gathering dwc:Events, this is the date-time when the gathering took place.
skos:example: `1963-03-08T14:07-0600` (8 Mar 1963 at 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `2009-02-20T08:40Z` (20 February 2009 8:40am UTC); `2018-08-29T15:19` (3:19pm local time on 29 August 2018); `1809-02-12` (some time during 12 February 1809); `1906-06` (some time in June 1906); `1971` (some time in the year 1971); `2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z` (some time during the interval between 1 March 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC); `1900/1909` (some time during the interval between the beginning of the year 1900 and the end of the year 1909); `2007-11-13/15` (some time in the interval between 13 November 2007 and 15 November 2007)

skos:definition: The time or interval during which a dwc:Event occurred.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a time of day that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.
skos:example: `14:07-0600` (2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `08:40:21Z` (8:40:21am UTC); `13:00:00Z/15:30:00Z` (the interval between 1pm UTC and 3:30pm UTC)

skos:definition: The earliest integer day of the year on which a dwc:Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
skos:example: `1` (1 January); `32` (1 February); `366` (31 December); `365` (30 December in a leap year, 31 December in a non-leap year)

skos:definition: The latest integer day of the year on which a dwc:Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
skos:example: `1` (1 January); `32` (1 February); `366` (31 December); `365` (30 December in a leap year, 31 December in a non-leap year)

skos:definition: The four-digit year in which a dwc:Event occurred, according to the Common Era Calendar.
The integer month in which a dwc:Event occurred.
The integer day of the month on which a dwc:Event occurred.
The verbatim original representation of the date and time information for a dwc:Event.
The original textual description of a dcterms:Location of a dwc:Event.
skos:example: `25 km NNE Bariloche por R. Nac. 237`

skos:definition: The original description of the elevation (altitude, usually above sea level) of a dcterms:Location.
The original description of the depth below a local surface.
The verbatim original spatial coordinates of a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

skos:definition: The verbatim original latitude of a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

skos:definition: The verbatim original longitude of a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

skos:definition: The coordinate format for dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude or dwc:verbatimCoordinates.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which coordinates given in dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude, or dwc:verbatimCoordinates are based.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `unknown`.

skos:definition: A categorical description of the extent to which the georeference has been verified to represent the best possible spatial description for the dcterms:Location of a dwc:Occurrence.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
skos:example: `unable to georeference`; `requires georeference`; `requires verification`; `verified by data custodian`; `verified by contributor`

skos:definition: A category or description of the habitat in which a dwc:Event occurred.
A numeric value for a measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling dwc:Event.
skos:note: A dwc:sampleSizeValue must have a corresponding dwc:sampleSizeUnit.

skos:definition: The unit of measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling dwc:Event.
skos:note: A dwc:sampleSizeUnit must have a corresponding dwc:sampleSizeValue, e.g., `5` for dwc:sampleSizeValue with `metre` for dwc:sampleSizeUnit.

skos:definition: The amount of effort expended during a dwc:Event.
skos:example: `40 trap-nights`; `10 observer-hours`; `10 km by foot`; `30 km by car`

skos:definition: One of a) an indicator of the existence of, b) a reference to (publication, URI), or c) the text of notes taken in the field about a dwc:Event.
A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
skos:example: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

skos:definition: Comments or notes about a dwc:Event.
skos:example: `After the recent rains the river is nearly at flood stage.`

skos:definition: An identifier a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: An identifier for the geographic region within which the dcterms:Location occurred.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
skos:example: `http://vocab.getty.edu/tgn/1002002`  (Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur, Territorio Nacional de la Tierra del Fuego, Argentina).

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of geographic names less specific than the information captured in dwc:locality.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `), with terms in order from least specific to most specific.
skos:example: `North Atlantic Ocean`; `South America | Argentina | Patagonia | Parque Nacional Nahuel Huapi | Neuquén | Los Lagos` with accompanying values `South America` (continent) `Argentina` (country), `Neuquén` (first order division), and `Los Lagos` (second order division)

skos:definition: The name of the continent in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

skos:definition: The name of the water body in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

skos:definition: The name of the island group in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

skos:definition: The name of the island on or near which a dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

skos:definition: The name of the country or major administrative unit in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

skos:definition: The standard code for the country in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 country code. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

skos:definition: The name of the next smaller administrative region than country (state, province, canton, department, region, etc.) in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if a dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if a dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

skos:definition: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than dwc:stateProvince (county, shire, department, etc.) in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

skos:definition: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than county (city, municipality, etc.) in which a dcterms:Location occurs. Do not use this term for a nearby named place that does not contain the actual location.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if a dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if a dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term `higherGeography` or in the term `locality`, or both.

skos:definition: The specific description of the place.
skos:note: Less specific geographic information can be provided in other geographic terms (higherGeography, continent, country, stateProvince, county, municipality, waterBody, island, islandGroup). This term may contain information modified from the original to correct perceived errors or standardize the description.
skos:example: `Bariloche, 25 km NNE via Ruta Nacional 40 (=Ruta 237)`; `Queets Rainforest, Olympic National Park`

skos:definition: The lower limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.
The upper limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.
The vertical datum used as the reference upon which the values in the elevation terms are based.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The lesser depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.
The greater depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.

The lesser distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
skos:example: `-1.5` (below the surface); `4.2` (above the surface); For a 1.5 meter sediment core from the bottom of a lake (at depth 20m) at 300m elevation: verbatimElevation: `300m` minimumElevationInMeters: `300`, maximumElevationInMeters: `300`, verbatimDepth: `20m`, minimumDepthInMeters: `20`, maximumDepthInMeters: `20`, minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `0`, maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `-1.5`.

skos:definition: The greater distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
skos:example: `-1.5` (below the surface); `4.2` (above the surface); For a 1.5 meter sediment core from the bottom of a lake (at depth 20m) at 300m elevation: verbatimElevation: `300m` minimumElevationInMeters: `300`, maximumElevationInMeters: `300`, verbatimDepth: `20m`, minimumDepthInMeters: `20`, maximumDepthInMeters: `20`, minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `0`, maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `-1.5`.

skos:definition: Comments or notes about a dcterms:Location.
The geographic latitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in dwc:geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: Positive values are north of the Equator, negative values are south of it. Legal values lie between -90 and 90, inclusive.

skos:definition: The geographic longitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in dwc:geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: Positive values are east of the Greenwich Meridian, negative values are west of it. Legal values lie between -180 and 180, inclusive.

skos:definition: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which the geographic coordinates given in dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude as based.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `unknown`.

skos:definition: The horizontal distance (in meters) from the given dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude describing the smallest circle containing the whole of the dcterms:Location.
skos:note: Leave the value empty if the uncertainty is unknown, cannot be estimated, or is not applicable (because there are no coordinates). Zero is not a valid value for this term.
skos:example: `30` (reasonable lower limit on or after 2000-05-01 of a GPS reading under good conditions if the actual precision was not recorded at the time); `100` (reasonable lower limit before 2000-05-01 of a GPS reading under good conditions if the actual precision was not recorded at the time); `71` (uncertainty for a UTM coordinate having 100 meter precision and a known spatial reference system)

skos:definition: A decimal representation of the precision of the coordinates given in a dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude.
skos:example: `0.00001` (normal GPS limit for decimal degrees); `0.000278` (nearest second); `0.01667` (nearest minute); `1.0` (nearest degree)

skos:definition: The ratio of the area of the point-radius (dwc:decimalLatitude, dwc:decimalLongitude, dwc:coordinateUncertaintyInMeters) to the area of the true (original, or most specific) spatial representation of a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given point-radius does not completely contain the original representation. The pointRadiusSpatialFit is undefined (and should be left empty) if the original representation is any geometry without area (e.g., a point or polyline) and without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same geometry (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, the pointRadiusSpatialFit is 1. Detailed explanations with graphical examples can be found in the Georeferencing Best Practices, Chapman and Wieczorek, 2020 (https://doi.org/10.15468/doc-gg7h-s853).

skos:definition: A Well-Known Text (WKT) representation of the shape (footprint, geometry) that defines a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: A dcterms:Location may have both a point-radius representation (see dwc:decimalLatitude) and a footprint representation, and they may differ from each other.
skos:example: `POLYGON ((10 20, 11 20, 11 21, 10 21, 10 20))` (the one-degree bounding box with opposite corners at longitude=10, latitude=20 and longitude=11, latitude=21)

skos:definition: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which the geometry given in dwc:footprintWKT is based.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `unknown`. It is also permitted to provide the SRS in Well-Known-Text, especially if no EPSG code provides the necessary values for the attributes of the SRS. Do not use this term to describe the SRS of a dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude, nor of any verbatim coordinates - use dwc:geodeticDatum and dwc:verbatimSRS instead.
skos:example: `epsg:4326`; `GEOGCS['GCS_WGS_1984', DATUM['D_WGS_1984', SPHEROID['WGS_1984',6378137,298.257223563]], PRIMEM['Greenwich',0], UNIT['Degree',0.0174532925199433]]` (WKT for the standard WGS84 Spatial Reference System EPSG:4326)

skos:definition: The ratio of the area of the footprint (footprintWKT) to the area of the true (original, or most specific) spatial representation of a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given footprint does not completely contain the original representation. The dwc:footprintSpatialFit is undefined (and should be left empty) if the original representation is any geometry without area (e.g., a point or polyline) and without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same geometry (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, a dwc:footprintSpatialFit is 1.

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who determined a georeference (spatial representation) for a dcterms:Location.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

skos:definition: An identifier for the Agent who georeferenced a dwc:Event.

skos:definition: A Web URL for a statement of the ownership and usage rights for this resource.

skos:note: A controlled value string describing the technical format of the resource (file format or physical medium). The string SHOULD be a controlled value from the Audiovisual Core Controlled Vocabulary for Dublin Core format, although it MAY be any Media Type (MIME type) value from the IANA list of Media Types (https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml) or any commonly used file extension string. See also the entry for dcterms:format in the Audiovisual Core term list document and see the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces, https://web.archive.org/web/20171126043657/https://github.com/dcmi/repository/blob/master/mediawiki_wiki/FAQ/DC_and_DCTERMS_Namespaces.md, for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces. It is best practice to use dcterms:format instead of dc:format whenever practical. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.

skos:definition: Information about rights held in and over the resource.
skos:note: A full-text, readable copyright statement, as required by the national legislation of the copyright holder. On collections, this applies to all contained objects, unless the object itself has a different statement. Do not place just the name of the copyright holder(s) here! That belongs in a list in the xmpRights:Owner field, which SHOULD be supplied if dc:rights is not 'Public Domain', which is appropriate only if the resource is known to be not under copyright. At least one of dcterms:rights and dc:rights MUST be supplied but, when feasible, supplying both might make the metadata more widely useful. They MUST specify the same rights. This expresses rights over the media resource, not over the metadata text. In case of ambiguity, dcterms:rights prevails. See also the entry for dcterms:rights in the Audiovisual Core Term List document and see the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces, https://web.archive.org/web/20171126043657/https://github.com/dcmi/repository/blob/master/mediawiki_wiki/FAQ/DC_and_DCTERMS_Namespaces.md, for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
skos:example: `Copyright XY 2008, all rights reserved`; `© 2008 XY Museum`; `Public Domain`; `Copyright unknown`

skos:definition: A list of legal owners of the resource.

Note: Audiovisual Core guidelines on value format are less restrictive than is specified in the IPTC guidelines. Some providers use dc:publisher for this purpose, but it seems doubtful that the publisher is by necessity the copyright owner. skos:definition: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

See also the entry for dcterms:source in the Audiovisual Core term list document and see the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces, https://web.archive.org/web/20171126043657/https://github.com/dcmi/repository/blob/master/mediawiki_wiki/FAQ/DC_and_DCTERMS_Namespaces.md, for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces. skos:definition: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.

Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.

skos:definition: An identifier for the entity primarily responsible for making the resource.
skos:note: An identifier for the person or organization responsible for creating the media resource. Note that the Creator need not be the Copyright Owner. See the entry for dcterms:creator in the Audiovisual Core term list document and see the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces, https://web.archive.org/web/20171126043657/https://github.com/dcmi/repository/blob/master/mediawiki_wiki/FAQ/DC_and_DCTERMS_Namespaces.md, for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces.

skos:definition: The date and time the resource was created. For a digital file, this need not match a file-system creation time. For a freshly created resource, it should be close to that time, modulo the time taken to write the file. Later file transfer, copying, and so on, can make the file-system time arbitrarily different.
skos:note: The date of the creation of the original resource from which the digital media was derived or created. The date and time MUST comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004, https://www.iso.org/standard/40874.html. AC datetime values MAY also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus ("forward slash", '/'). When applied to a media resource with temporal extent such as audio or video, this property indicates the startTime of the recording. What constitutes "original" is determined by the metadata author. Example: Digitization of a photographic slide of a map would normally give the date at which the map was created; however a photographic work of art including the same map as its content may give the date of the original photographic exposure. Imprecise or unknown dates can be represented as ISO dates or ranges. Compare also Date and Time Digitized in the Resource Creation Vocabulary. See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601, for further explanation and examples.

skos:definition: Date on which the resource was changed.
skos:note: Date that the media resource was altered. skos:definition: The names of, references to, or descriptions of the methods or protocols used in making an Assertion.
An identifier for a Protocol used to make an Assertion.
A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with an Assertion.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
skos:example: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

skos:definition: Comments or notes about an Assertion.
An identifier for a Citation.
An identifier for a Survey.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: The category that best matches the nature of a Citation.
The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Citation.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for citationType is given.
A bibliographic reference for the resource.
skos:note: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.
skos:example: `Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, UC Berkeley. MVZ Mammal Collection (Arctos). Record ID: http://arctos.database.museum/guid/MVZ:Mamm:165861?seid=101356. Source: http://ipt.vertnet.org:8080/ipt/resource.do?r=mvz_mammal.` (Occurrence example); `https://www.gbif.org/species/2439608 Source: GBIF Taxonomic Backbone` (Taxon example); `Rand, K.M., Logerwell, E.A. The first demersal trawl survey of benthic fish and invertebrates in the Beaufort Sea since the late 1970s. Polar Biol 34, 475–488 (2011). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00300-010-0900-2` (Event example)

skos:definition: The number of the page on which the citation occurs in the cited reference.
skos:note: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.
skos:example: `Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, UC Berkeley. MVZ Mammal Collection (Arctos). Record ID: http://arctos.database.museum/guid/MVZ:Mamm:165861?seid=101356. Source: http://ipt.vertnet.org:8080/ipt/resource.do?r=mvz_mammal.` (Occurrence example); `https://www.gbif.org/species/2439608 Source: GBIF Taxonomic Backbone` (Taxon example); `Rand, K.M., Logerwell, E.A. The first demersal trawl survey of benthic fish and invertebrates in the Beaufort Sea since the late 1970s. Polar Biol 34, 475–488 (2011). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00300-010-0900-2` (Event example)

skos:definition: An identifier for the reference in which a Citation occurs.
The category that best matches the nature of a reference.
The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of reference.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for referenceType is given.
The year the reference in a Citation was published.
An indication of whether the reference for a Citation was peer reviewed.
Comments or notes about a Citation.
An unambiguous reference to a resource within a given context.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to identify a resource by means of a string conforming to a formal identification system.

skos:definition: An identifier for a Survey.
The category or system that best matches the nature of an Identifier.
The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Identifier.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for identifierType is given.
A language in which an Identifier is presented.
skos:note: Recommended best prectice is to use an ISO639-2 three-letter language code.

skos:definition: An identifier for a Protocol.
An identifier for a Survey.
An identifier for a SurveyTarget.
An identifier for a dwc:Event that is an biotic survey.
The type of scope a SurveyTarget describes.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of survey target.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for surveyTargetType is given.
The value of a characteristic sought for the surveyTarget for a given surveyTargetType.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of survey target value.
The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for surveyTargetValue is given.
The units associated with the surveyTargetValue.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

skos:definition: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of survey target unit.
The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for surveyTargetUnit is given.

A term to declare whether an instance of the SurveyTarget is an included scope or an excluded scope. Combinations of SurveyTarget records of inclusions and exclusions can define complex scopes such as all flying adult Aves except Passeriformes.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is use a controlled vocabulary consisting of 'include' and 'exclude' only.

skos:definition: A declaration of whether the counts for an instance of the SurveyTarget report everything that matches the declared SurveyTarget. If they do, this enables inference of absence of detection for everything in that SurveyTarget that is included but that does not appear in the count.
An identifier for a Survey.
An identifier for a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

skos:definition: Total number of individual sites surveyed during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Site refers to the location at which observations are made or samples/measurements are taken. The site can be at any level of hierarchy.

skos:definition: Textual description of a hierarchical sampling design.
skos:note: Site refers to the location at which observations are made or samples/measurements are taken. The site can be at any level of hierarchy.

skos:definition: Original textual description of site(s).
skos:note: Site refers to the location at which observations are made or samples/measurements are taken. The site can be at any level of hierarchy. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).
skos:example: `Wet flatwoods | Wet depression surrounded by mesic longleaf pine flatwoods | Ground cover of thick Andropogon spp., Sporobolus floridanus, Vaccinium spp, Rhynchospora spp., Centella erecta, Panicum rigidulum.`

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of original site names.
skos:note: Site refers to the location at which observations are made or samples/measurements are taken. The site can be at any level of hierarchy. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).
skos:example: `East Coastal Fringe | St. Marks Wildlife Management Area`; `S1 | S2 | C1 | C2 | R14 | R22 | W1`

skos:definition: The numeric value for the total area of a geospatial scope of a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Geospatial scope refers to a dwc:Event location reported using the terms organized in Darwin Core under dcterms:Location. This area is always greater than or equal to the eco:totalAreaSampledValue. An eco:geospatialScopeAreaValue must have a corresponding eco:geospatialScopeAreaUnit.

skos:definition: The units associated with eco:geospatialScopeAreaValue
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. For units containing exponents, use characters from the Unicode Latin-1 Supplement character set (hex 00B2 for squared and 00B3 for cubed). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: The numeric value for the total area surveyed during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: This area is always less than or equal to the eco:geospatialScopeAreaValue. An eco:totalAreaSampledValue must have a corresponding eco:totalAreaSampledUnit.

skos:definition: The units associated with eco:totalAreaSampledValue
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. For units containing exponents, use characters from the Unicode Latin-1 Supplement character set (hex 00B2 for squared and 00B3 for cubed). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: A list of weather or climatic conditions present during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a key:value encoding schema for a data interchange format such as JSON.

skos:definition: A description of any extreme weather or environmental conditions that may have affected a dwc:Event.
skos:example: `flooding during week 3 of surveys`; `rockslide at site 2`

skos:definition: The numeric value for the duration of a dwc:Event.
skos:example: `An eco:eventDurationValue must have a corresponding eco:eventDurationUnit.`

skos:definition: The units associated with the eco:eventDurationValue.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: Statement about whether the taxonomic completeness of a dwc:Event was assessed.
skos:note: This term is meant to alert users that the inventory was conducted in such a way that all of the target taxa (the combination of eco:targetTaxonomicScope and eco:excludedTaxonomicScope) should have been detectable if they were present during a dwc:Event. This term can provide data users with a qualitative measure of how comprehensively an area has been surveyed, which assists in interpreting species populations, areas of occupancy, inferring species absences, etc. This term is only relevant if a dwc:Event used restricted search or open search methods. If taxonomic completeness was assessed, the methods used or an explanation of the basis of the completeness should be stated in eco:taxonCompletenessProtocols. Recommended best practice is to use controlled value strings from the controlled vocabulary designated for use with this term, listed at http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/tcr/. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: A description of or reference (publication, URL) to the methods used to determine eco:taxonCompletenessReported.
skos:note: This term allows users to determine how comprehensively an area has been sampled. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
skos:example: `census | based on sampling effort`; `based on species accumulation curves`

skos:definition: Taxonomic absences were reported.
skos:note: Absences can be reported at any taxonomic level.

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of taxa reported absent during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Absences can be reported at any taxonomic level. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
skos:example: `Parabuteo unicinctus | Geranoaetus melanoleucus`; `Cetoniinae | Aclopinae | Cyclocephala modesta`

skos:definition: One or more dwc:Organisms of taxa outside the target taxonomic scope (the combination of eco:targetTaxonomicScope and eco:excludedTaxonomicScope) were detected and reported for this dwc:Event.
skos:note: This term is meant to alert users to the presence of non-target taxa (in some disciplines called “bycatch”) reported in this dwc:Event. This term is relevant only if a target taxonomic scope is declared. Taxonomic scope is based on the combination of eco:targetTaxonomicScope and eco:excludedTaxonomicScope. Examination of the taxonomic scope is needed in order to identify the non-target taxa. It should be possible to confirm the expectations by investigating a dwc:Occurrences in this dwc:Event and in its child dwc:Events (if available) or by exploring eco:nonTargetTaxa for this dwc:Event (if populated). The value of this term should be 'true' if dwc:Occurrences of taxa outside the taxonomic scope as defined at the time of a dwc:Event are reported, otherwise the value of this term should be 'false'.

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of taxa reported during a dwc:Event that are outside of the target taxonomic scope (the combination of eco:targetTaxonomicScope and eco:excludedTaxonomicScope).
skos:note: This term is meant to allow the full list of taxa that are considered outside of the taxonomic scope and yet were reported in the dataset to be shared. This term is relevant only if a target taxonomic scope is declared and eco:hasNonTargetTaxa is ‘true’. Taxonomic scope is based on the combination of eco:targetTaxonomicScope and eco:excludedTaxonomicScope. Non-target taxa (in some disciplines called “bycatch”) can be reported at any taxonomic level. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
skos:example: `Parabuteo unicinctus | Geranoaetus melanoleucus`; `Cetoniinae | Aclopinae | Cyclocephala modesta`

skos:definition: Every dwc:Organism that was outside of the target taxonomic scope (the combination of eco:targetTaxonomicScope and eco:excludedTaxonomicScope) and detected during a dwc:Event, and that was detectable using the given protocol (given in eco:protocolDescriptions and dwc:samplingProtocol), was reported.
skos:note: This term is meant to inform a user of the data whether there were non-target taxa that were detected, but left unreported. This term is only relevant if a dwc:Event used restricted search or open search methods and if a target taxonomic scope is declared. Taxonomic scope is based on the combination of eco:targetTaxonomicScope and eco:excludedTaxonomicScope. Within dwc:Events that used either a restricted search or an open search method and declared a taxonomic scope, if all dwc:Organisms that are not included within the target taxonomic scope and that were detected during a dwc:Event were reported, the value of this term should be 'true', otherwise the value of this term should be ‘false'.

skos:definition: One or more dwc:Organisms outside the target organismal scopes (eco:targetDegreeOfEstablishmentScope, eco:targetGrowthFormScope, and eco:targetLifeStageScope) were detected and reported for this dwc:Event.
skos:note: This term is meant to alert users to the presence of non-target organisms (in some disciplines called “bycatch”) reported in this dwc:Event. This term is relevant only if a target organismal scope is declared. Organismal scope is based on the combination of all of the following terms: eco:targetLifeStageScope, eco:excludedLifeStageScope, eco:targetDegreeOfEstablishmentScope, eco:excludedDegreeOfEstablishmentScope, eco:targetGrowthFormScope, and eco:excludedGrowthFormScope. Examination of the organismal scope is needed in order to identify the non-target dwc:Organisms. It should be possible to confirm the expectations by investigating a dwc:Occurrences in this dwc:Event and in its child dwc:Events (if available). The value of this term should be 'true' if dwc:Occurrences of dwc:Organisms outside the organismal scope(s) as defined at the time of a dwc:Event are reported, otherwise the value of this term should be 'false'.

skos:definition: The verbatim original description of a dwc:Event scope.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is first to populate explicit scope terms to the fullest extent possible (e.g., eco:targetTaxonomicScope). It is not recommended to use this term in assessing absence or completeness.

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who made a taxonomic determination of a dwc:Organism.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

skos:definition: The identifier for the Agent who made a taxonomic determination of a dwc:Organism.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to provide a single identifier that disambiguates the details of the identifying agent. If a list is used, the order of the identifiers on the list should not be assumed to convey any semantics. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

skos:definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of references (publication, global unique identifier, URI) used in a dwc:Identification.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
skos:example: `Aves del Noroeste Patagonico. Christie et al. 2004.`; `Stebbins, R. Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians. 3rd Edition. 2003. | Irschick, D.J. and Shaffer, H.B. (1997). The polytypic species revisited: Morphological differentiation among tiger salamanders (Ambystoma tigrinum) (Amphibia: Caudata). Herpetologica, 53(1), 30-49.`

skos:definition: A statement specifying whether data reported are derived from sampling events, ancillary data compiled from other sources, or a combination of both.
skos:note: This term is only relevant if a dwc:Event is an inventory. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: The types of data sources contributing to the compilation reported.
skos:note: This term is only relevant if a dwc:Event is a compilation in which one or more types of data sources were used. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary and separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: The types of search processes used to conduct the inventory.
skos:note: This term is only relevant if a dwc:Event represents an inventory. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: Categorical descriptive names for the methods used during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary and separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: A detailed description of the methods used during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: This description should be associated with protocols provided in eco:protocolNames. The description may include deviations from a protocol referred to in eco:protocolReferences. Recommended good practice is to provide information about instruments used, calibration, etc. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).
skos:example: `Three conventional harp traps (3.2m ht x 2.2m w) were established in flight path zones for a period of 4 hrs at dawn and dusk for a total of 10 trap nights. Traps were visited on an hourly basis during each deployment period and the trap catch recorded for species, size, weight, sex, age and maternal status.`

skos:definition: The references to the methods used during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).
skos:example: `Penguins from space: faecal stains reveal the location of emperor penguin colonies, https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1466-8238.2009.00467.x`

skos:definition: The number of dwc:Organisms collected or observed was reported.
skos:note: Typically the abundance values would be reported in a dwc:organismQuantity and dwc:organismQuantityType terms for the child dwc:Occurrence records for this dwc:Event.

skos:definition: A maximum number of dwc:Organisms was reported, as specified or restricted by the protocol used.
skos:note: Values of abundance cap should be captured under the term eco:abundanceCap.

skos:definition: The reported maximum number of dwc:Organisms.
A vegetation cover metric was reported.
skos:note: Typically values or descriptions of vegetation cover would be captured under the term eco:verbatimSiteDescriptions.

skos:definition: The total detected quantity for a dwc:Taxon (including subcategories thereof) in a dwc:Event is given explicitly in a single record (dwc:organismQuantity value) for that dwc:Taxon.
skos:note: Recommended values are 'true' and 'false'. This term is only relevant if dwc:organismQuantity is a number. For a detailed explanation, see http://rs.tdwg.org/eco/docs/inclusive/.

skos:definition: Specimen vouchers were collected during a dwc:Event.
A list (concatenated and separated) of the names or acronyms of the institutions where vouchers collected during a dwc:Event were deposited.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).

skos:definition: Material samples were collected during a dwc:Event.
A list (concatenated and separated) of material sample types collected during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary and separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: A person, group, or organization that performed the sampling.
skos:note: The sampling dwc:Event could be at any level of hierarchy. In the case of a higher level (parent) dwc:Event, include all the organizations or people involved in the child dwc:Events that contributed to the parent dwc:Event. Recommended best practice is to separate multiple values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
skos:example: `North American Butterfly Association`; `KK Wall`; `JJ Green`; `LL Pink and FF Grey | Aspen Center for Environmental Studies`

skos:definition: The identifier for the Agent who performed the sampling.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to provide a single identifier that disambiguates the details of the sampling agent. If a list is used, the order of the identifiers on the list should not be assumed to convey any semantics. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

skos:definition: The sampling effort associated with a dwc:Event was reported.
skos:note: Typically values of effort would be captured under the terms eco:samplingEffortValue and eco:samplingEffortUnit.

skos:definition: A description of or reference (publication or URL) to the methods used to determine the sampling effort.
skos:note: This description should be associated with the values reported in eco:samplingEffortValue and eco:samplingEffortUnit. This is a specialization of eco:protocolDescriptions focused on effort, distinct from the survey method. The effort relates to the intensity of sampling and therefore can assist in interpreting estimates of completeness. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
skos:example: `40 box traps deployed at even spacings along 4 parallel 100m transects placed 50m apart and visited at 6 hourly intervals over a 48 hour period`; `2 people occupying a bird hide for a period of 8 hours and undertaking a 30 minute count of species within the 150 degree field of view every 2 hours`; `A single baited camera trap station with motion sensor trigger, deployed for a period of 10 days and configured for detecting large fauna moving through a known traffic way`

skos:definition: An identifier for a Protocol used to determine sampling effort.
The numeric value for the sampling effort expended during a dwc:Event.
skos:note: This term is meant to capture the total sampling effort value. To express details of how the effort was determined use eco:samplingEffortProtocol. For compilations it is recommend not to infer effort. An eco:samplingEffortValue must have a corresponding eco:samplingEffortUnit.

skos:definition: The units associated with the eco:samplingEffortValue.
skos:note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

skos:definition: Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.
skos:example: `location information not given for endangered species`; `collector identities withheld | ask about tissue samples`

skos:definition: Actions taken to make the shared data less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request.
skos:example: `coordinates generalized from original GPS coordinates to the nearest half degree grid cell`
